Award.AwardTitle: How Does the Plant Say-No More?: A Molecular Genetic Approach to Nodule Number Regulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The colonization of roots of plants in the legume family by nitrogen-fixing bacteria is regulated by a complex series of interactions between the symbiotic partners. The endpoint is a specialized organ called a nodule, which is formed by the plant roots to house the bacteria. In exchange for carbon provided by the plant, the bacteria provide the plant with nitrogen from the air, allowing legumes the unique ability to grow in the absence of soil nitrogen. This project focuses on the plant's control of the symbiosis, with the genetically enabled model species Medicago truncatula as the plant host and Sinorhizobia as the bacterial symbiont. The mechanisms by which the plant regulates the number of nodules it forms will be studied. The PI has shown that regulation of nodule number occurs by way of signals that travel between roots and shoots. Four questions about how the root and shoot signal to each other remain unanswered:

What is the nodulation signal to the shoot?
What perceives the signal in the shoot?
What is the nature of the signal to the root?
What receives the signal in the root?

A combination of physiological, genetic and biochemical approaches will be employed to identify the signals and determine how they are perceived. Towards this end investigators will analyze the genes, nutrients and plant hormones involved in regulating responses to the signals. Currently-known as well as new genes and proteins that function in this pathway will be characterized

Nitrogen fertilizer is costly to produce and excessive fertilizer application is a source of groundwater pollution, making the unique ability of legumes to grow in the absence of soil nitrogen highly desirable for agriculture. Because the nodule number regulatory pathway is also involved in root growth, the results of this project are critical to future manipulation of nodulation in agriculture and for revealing how all plants coordinate shoot and root growth. The project will train two doctoral students and four undergraduates, while providing summer research opportunities to several high school students. The lead investigator will engage in outreach by teaching best practices in research ethics through established university programs and disseminating the results of this project at scientific meetings and university programs targeted to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nodulation is an interaction between legume plants and rhizobia bacteria, an elaborate molecular communication in which the plant and bacterial partners signal and respond to each other through a complex series of molecular events, resulting in specialized structures formed by the plant to house the bacteria, called nodules. Nodules allow the plant to obtain nitrogen from the air instead of the soil so that legume plants can grow without added nitrogen fertilizer.  This project focused on the plant side of the symbiosis between Medicago truncatula (a legume plant) and Sinorhizobia (a bacterium that fixes nitrogen) in order to determine how the plant regulates the number of nodules that form in the interaction and gain insight into how to establish this interaction in other plants.

            The goal of the project was increased understanding of the signal transduction pathway.  The project focused on four questions about how the root and shoot of the plant signal to each other during nodulation: (1) What is the signal to the shoot that the interaction has started? (2) What complex of molecules perceives the signal in the shoot? (3) What is the signal to the root that enough nodules have been made and nodulation should stop? And  (4) What complex or molecule receives the signal in the root? 

            The investigators addressed the four questions above by using genetic and molecular resources in M. truncatula. By looking at changes in the timing of regulation in response to genetic and external signals, including nutrients and plant hormones, an additional regulatory signal that occurs 15 days after the initial interaction was discovered.  The published discovery suggests multiple regulatory pathways and multiple inputs for nodule number regulation, adding an additional layer to the known complexity of the signaling.

            Using both a biochemical and a genetic approach, the investigators placed currently known genes into a regulatory pathway and discovered more genes involved in the pathway. Some of these discoveries are published and some are still ongoing. Together with discoveries by other groups, it is now known that hormonal signaling causes production of a small peptide, modified with a sugar, that is sent to the plant shoot when the interaction starts. A complex of multiple receptor proteins conserved across all plants, even those that do not nodulate, receives the signal and transduces it into a response that is transmitted through hormone movement back to the root.  However, the molecules that receive the signal in the root (question 4 above) still remain unknown. The investigators discovered several genes and proteins that affect the signaling of the receptor complex, making this interaction also more complex than originally thought.

            Understanding the regulation of nodulation has important impacts for agriculture. Nitrogen fertilizer is costly to make, both in terms of capital and carbon footprint, and excessive fertilizer application is a source of groundwater pollution. The ability of legumes to form a symbiosis with bacteria allows legumes to grow without the application of nitrogen fertilizer.  Because the nodule number regulatory pathway is also involved in root growth, the results of this project are critical to future manipulation of the symbiosis in agriculture but also for revealing how even non-legume plants coordinate shoot and root growth.

 The project trained three doctoral students  (two from underrepresented groups) as well as gave lab rotation experience to two more (one from an underrepresented group). Seven undergraduate researchers, the majority of them female, researched in the lab for periods ranging from 6 months to 3 years, and two high school students participated in summer research.

The lead investigator engaged in university and community outreach, disseminating best practices in research ethics as part of a university-wide program and supporting the training of over 100 middle school students during the four years by providing materials and teaching support for the DNA Learning Center. She also provided genetics learning activities or teaching support for the State 4-H Congress, the Greenville Zoo, and spoke to the general public on GMOs and plant biology through invited lectures and newspaper articles.
